The Great Defender: 'Our democracy is dead.'

30/05/2013

The Government has proposed changes to the way Legal Aid for criminal cases are funded. Michael Turner QC tells Laura Hughes the frightening truth of what these changes could mean.

Image by

By undefined undefined

"What if one of your students was accused of a terrorism offense? What if one of your students was charged with rape, accused of murder, or of killing one of their children? Which is not beyond the realms of possibility?" Michael Turner QC, Chairman of the Criminal Bar Association, believes our system of justice is being quietly dismantled. A life can be ruined by inadequate representation, and for the past 32 years, Michael has been championed one of the greatest defenders of irrevocable cases of alleged murder, terrorism and rape. This is the Barrister who gained freedom for a man convicted of murdering the 13-year-old paper boy Carl Bridgewater, after 18 years. But now Michael is fighting perhaps the greatest miscarriage of justice of his profession. The Government has proposed changes to the way Legal Aid for criminal cases are funded, and the Ministry of Justice have outlined plans to reduce access to justice by depriving citizens of legal aid, or the right to representation by the Solicitor of their choice. I felt the wrath of Michael's infamous and brutal directness. How would this QC respond to those who argue those arrested, have committed an offence, and so shouldn't have the right to choose who will represent them? "Oh bloody hell, who says that? Let them come to me. I haven't heard anything so stupid in my life. If they are accused of a criminal offence I have no doubt that they would say that they were innocent, and they and their parents would seek the best representation in the world. Does it apply to them and no one else accused of crime? It's an accusation of crime against the individual, and we are talking about not just petty theft, we are talking about all sorts of things where you need proper specialisation. It is decimation to this profession."
"You will have juniors prosecuting murders, and that's where things will start to go wrong."
The fee cuts will mean that Barristers will no longer be able to work in chambers. Chambers will disappear as you know it, and many will give up. "Those at the publicly funded bar in contra distinction to the privately funded Bar will be cast to the four winds. Solicitors will be reduced from 16000 criminal providers across the country to a quarter of that number." Solicitors will be put on tiny contracts in relative terms worth then more than 1.6 million pounds. "They will not be able to sustain these contracts, and those contracts will not be fulfilled after three years. Then the big providers like, Eddie Stobart, Tesco's, Cerco and G4S will come in and take over the contracts. Bar solicitors will go in-house and the corporate mentality will take over the ethics of this profession. The profession will disappear because there's nothing to work for; there is no competition and no interest in doing a good job for one's client. You will be flogging to work for just PS35,000 per year. The judges are taken from the independent bar once judges are brought up by way of profession by this corporate ethos. They lose their independence. You lose your independence as a judiciary and our democracy is dead." Michael was made silk in 2002, "now I'll be a quasi-regarded QC Barrister with no incentive, and so you will have juniors doing murders as you do now, you will have juniors prosecuting murders, and that's where things will start to go wrong. The likes of me will only appear in private cases." Michael has been involved in some of the biggest injustices cases of the last 25 years. "The whole point about the bar is that the tramp has always been able to get the same advocate as the King. That will no longer be the case. Lives will be ruined both ways round. The victims of crime will not be represented and people who are guilty will get off. People who are innocent will go down." The Carl Bridgewater case would never have been uncovered as an injustice case, but for the work of the lawyers behind the scene Pro-bono. Likewise, Michael's 35 injustice cases helped bring down the notorious West Midlands Serious Crime Squad, disbanded in the eighties. "We brought down that squads, and if you thought that water boarding was invented in Guantanamo it was not, those were the kind of things that the Squad were doing; principally putting plastic bags over the heads of defendants in order to get a confession out of them." The Government is planning to introduce what is called a Quality Assurance Scheme for Advocates. In response to the suggestion that 'competitive tendering' for criminal legal aid, will save the taxpayer PS220 million a year over the next five years, "That's a complete load of bullocks. They have no idea if that's the actual figure at all. They've got all the money in the world to run a Rolls Royce system - this is an ideological attack on our profession and democracy." In 2005 the Labour party merged the magistrate's court into the Ministry of Justice and threw 6,000 civil servants at it, costing the tax payer PS1.5 billion. This was "probably the best example of Cameron's 'Big Society' in action. Lay volunteer magistrates, in their communities doing the small justice cases. That was wiped out. The magistrate's court association will want that back; most right thinking people will want it back. That will save you PS1.5 billion pounds - that is the entirety of your legal aid budget as it stands." On the subject of banking fraud cases, which I was told take 90 per cent of the legal aid budget, Michael says "the banks pay not a penny when they are defrauded, not a single penny. They write off their losses against tax. The tax payer pays for the criminal investigation, the tax payer pays for the criminal case, and when there's a conviction, the banks are handed their civil proceedings on a plate for their recovery. Thank you very much. And that is why the banks have no interest at all in doing anything about fraud prevention." Michael told me he doesn't believe strike is necessary, "I think we can do everything we can to bring our courts to a standstill if we need to, we won't work for these rates. Solicitors will support us, we won't sign up to a quality assurance scheme, and the court system will not function." Is it fair to say the government has a contradictory approach to the legal profession? With the Government handing out vast amounts of money to fund QCs in the Qatada case. "Of course they have a contradictory approach to the legal profession. It's completely contradictory when their velocity is to outsource everything and to bring in everything in-house to the Crown Prosecution service, with in-house advocates, which is costing the tax payer probably PS100 million more than it ever was. Then they are out-serving legal services in a variety of ways to the likes of Eddie Stobart, Cerco and Capita, which costs the tax payer a fortune. You just go down to the Baily- Cerco don't have enough staff." In a speech entitled, A Speech to would-be pupils, Michael denounces Capita as a private company that employs translators without qualification or CRB check and "who obtained the contract by falsely claiming they had reputed translators on their books when they did not. One journalist submitted two applications to this company one in his own name and one from his cat, the stated language being "ancient cat". He was not invited for an interview, his cat was." It costs PS110 a minute to run a court room with a jury. "You just have to do the maths, that's PS52,000 a day 256,000 a week, therefore any wastage in our state is costing the tax payer a fortune. Our courts are virtually at a standstill at the moment." Until Michael wins this fight, there is no future for law students at the criminal or civil bar. If these current proposals are implemented there will be virtually no pupillages available. We spoke of student apathy, "When I was a student we used to occupy all the time. So occupy, go on - get a bit of revolution in your belly. It's the most wonderful vocation in the world, but it's not going to be here unless the students break out and start doing something about it. I don't know what your university professors say to you, or what the law school says to you, but they lie through their top hat at you when they say it's realistic to expect tenancy. My chambers are probably the most popular chambers in England for pupillage. We have 1000 applicants each year for 4 places. Those of you who choose to join this profession whether it be as a barrister or solicitor will do so for one reason and one reason alone, and that is because you have the passion to do right and fear no one."
